stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on fixing bugs for the upcoming demo, focusing primarily on implementing and refining a new 'Yoshi Coin Radar' for the 7th mission in each level. This involved a major design change (making it a standard feature instead of a purchasable item), technical bug fixing (invisible lights), and UI/UX design (testing transparency effects).

development_findings.summary: The game's structure has been changed to include a seventh mission in each course, dedicated specifically to finding the level's egg coins.
development_findings.quote: I added the Yoshi coin mission as the seventh star in the act select if you count here, there's now seven stars instead of six.

development_findings.summary: The traditional Mario 64 '100 coin star' has been removed. Coins are now a global currency used for other purposes.
development_findings.quote: 100 commissions do not exist anymore. Points are global now.

development_findings.summary: The new coin radar is directly inspired by the treasure hunting radar from Sonic Adventure 1.
development_findings.quote: It is very similar to that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze solved a critical bug where dynamic lights were not appearing by discovering an obscure engine feature that prevents an object from spawning if a specific parameter is set to 255.
development_findings.quote: There's a functionality in the Mario 64 engine where if you set the beep harm free to 255 the object does not spawn. This is so fucking wild.

development_findings.summary: To solve UI clutter and color confusion with the coin radar, Kaze is implementing and testing a transparency-based system where an icon becomes more opaque as the player gets closer to the corresponding coin.
development_findings.quote: The closer you are to it the more solid it gets.

development_findings.summary: Kaze provides a status update on upcoming levels: Course 13 (Ice Castle) is 'basically done,' Course 14 (Craft World) is 'mostly done,' and Course 15 (Space Arcade) is 'halfway.'
A demo is being prepared. Kaze states that if players find a way to access levels not included in the demo, the game will intentionally crash as the assets won't be present.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy prioritizes avoiding player frustration, leading him to change the coin radar from a purchasable item to a built-in feature for the coin-hunting missions.
context_findings.quote: Imagine you have not bought the radar and you're doing a mission 7 and the game doesn't give you any hint at all. That's gonna suck. That's gonna be a miserable experience people are gonna hate that and I want to avoid that experience happening to anyone.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals a core design pillar for the game's economy: players will use collected coins to fund projects in the overworld, causing tangible changes to the game world.
context_findings.quote: The coins are gonna be there to buy overworld upgrades so like maybe there will be a guy that wants to build a bridge but he needs a donation of 500 coins to buy the materials... You're actually gonna affect the world by giving people money.

context_findings.summary: He believes that treasure hunt mechanics should not be overly simplified, valuing the feeling of a genuine hunt over straightforward objective markers.
context_findings.quote: Sure. It makes the game easier, but it makes the knuckles mission feel less like a treasure hunt, you know more like a Go everywhere a fucking idiot type thing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a pragmatic, tool-agnostic view on programming, stating that the language is less important than the programmer's skill and that C is sufficient for their needs.
context_findings.quote: Only bad programmers care about the programming language... C can already do everything we need.

context_findings.summary: Kaze makes a brief, personal comment about his minimalist wardrobe when a viewer points out he wears the same shirt often.
context_findings.quote: I only own like five or six shirts.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses significant frustration with software that has frequent, intrusive updates, specifically mentioning Parallel Launcher, which he only uses for compatibility testing.

biobak.summary: Biobak is working on a 'line of mushrooms' asset for Course 1, which Kaze is waiting to implement.
Kaze explicitly shows the new coin radar feature to Biobak during the stream to get his feedback.
Biobak brings up a sensitive topic about a potential Nintendo strike against Kaze, prompting a brief discussion.
biobak.quote: Any news on an intense strike topic I saw?

zeina.summary: Zeina was present at the beginning of the stream.
Kaze mentions asking Zeina to run an errand for the project, specifically to purchase a second N64 console.
zeina.quote: I was thinking of picking up a second n64 um so i wanted zainab to pick that up.

key_stories.title: The Invisible Lights Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze troubleshoots a perplexing bug where lights fail to appear. After debugging, he uncovers a bizarre, little-known feature of the original Mario 64 engine that was unintentionally preventing the objects from spawning, highlighting the challenges of working with legacy code.
key_stories.challenge: A bug was preventing dynamic lights from spawning in a specific area of Course 1, and the cause was not apparent from the code.
key_stories.process: Kaze investigated the code for the lights, confirmed they were being placed in the level and were active, but noticed their core function was not running. This led him to check the object's behavioral parameters, where he found the problematic value.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze discovered an obscure, hard-coded behavior in the original Mario 64 engine was responsible. By understanding this engine quirk, he was able to identify the cause and fix the bug, showcasing his deep technical knowledge of the platform.
key_stories.key_quote: There's a functionality in the Mario 64 engine where if you set the beep harm free to 255 the object does not spawn. This is so fucking wild.

key_stories.title: Designing the Radar UI
key_stories.summary: The team needed an intuitive UI for the new coin radar. After dismissing color-based blinking as too confusing, Kaze experimented with using transparency as an indicator, a more subtle solution that shows promise.
key_stories.challenge: How to visually represent the coin radar without it being distracting or confusing, especially since coin colors change per level.
key_stories.process: The team considered multiple ideas, including color-coded blinking and brightness changes. Kaze noted the issue with color clashes and distracting blinking. He then implemented a transparency-based indicator live on stream to evaluate its effectiveness.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze prototyped a solution where uncollected coin icons are semi-transparent and become more opaque as the player gets closer. This avoids color-clash issues and is less visually distracting than constant blinking, though it's still under consideration.
key_stories.key_quote: This is kind of nice honestly. The closer you are to it the more solid it gets.

key_stories.title: The Radar's Purpose
key_stories.summary: Kaze re-evaluated the coin radar's role in the game. To prioritize a good player experience over item-based progression, he shifted it from an optional purchase to a core, built-in mechanic for all coin-hunting missions.
key_stories.challenge: The original plan for the coin radar was for it to be a purchasable item, but this could create a 'miserable experience' for players who didn't buy it before attempting the coin-collecting mission.
key_stories.process: Kaze considered the player's perspective and realized a player could enter the 7th mission without knowing a radar item even existed. To prevent this frustration, he fundamentally changed the feature's role, integrating it into the mission itself rather than making it an optional upgrade.
key_stories.outcome: The radar is no longer a purchasable item. It is now a standard, automatically-equipped feature during the 7th mission of every level, ensuring all players have the necessary tool for the treasure hunt.
key_stories.key_quote: I want to avoid that experience happening to anyone.
